g.text: Day 15: Ansible Zero to Hero
How to install Ansible on Linux?
- sudo apt update
- sudo apt install ansible
So at the first place we use ansible to automate task of configuring servers, so using one server we configure more servers.
So to do so we need to install ansible on a main/ansible server and automate things on all other target servers.
So the prerequisite inorder to configure other servers through ansible server is that, ansible server should be able to access other target
servers without any passwords or simply password less authentication.
How to enable Password less Authentication??
step 1: On Ansible Server do ssh-keygen(this will create public-private key)
this will create public and private keys from which we need "id_rsa.pub".
step 2: Open the file "id_rsa.pub" and copy the public key.
step 3: Now login into target server.
step 4: In Target Server do ssh-keygen.
step 5: This will also generate public and private key but along with this it will also
generate file named "authorized_keys".
step 6: Open the file "authorized_keys".
step 7: Now paste the public key of Ansible server which we copied in step 2, inside the
target server's authorized_keys file.
What are Ansible "Adhoc Commands"??
For smaller commands or tasks we don't have to write ansible playbooks, rather we can use
these adhoc commands.
for eg: Suppose we got task from manager that we have to create a file on 100 servers.
so here for creating a single file we cannot write an entire playbook, since its just one task we will
write an adhoc command.
How to Write Ansible "Adhoc Commands"??
Writing this commands are easy, we just need a file called inventory.
- this inventory file consists of all the ip addresses of target machine.
- we can even make groups of this ip address.
- for now suppose our inventory file only has 1 target machine ip address.
- so commands would be
- ansible -i inventory 127.68.2.1 -m "shell" -a "touch testFile".
. Here -m"" means module, like ansible provides some modules that are helpful from excuting some task.
. -a"" means command that you like to excecute
How to make groups in inventory file??
- we can group some server into categories like suppose some server are backend specific and some are
for Devlopment Puropose.
- now here is how you can group them in inventory file:
. [Backend_Servers]
[Development_Servers]
- now suppose you want to add file only on Development_Server we can do using
- ansible -i inventory Development_Servers -m "shell" -a "touch testFile2"
How to Write "Ansible Playbooks"??
- so now task is to Install nginix and start the nginix server.
- we have to write ansible playbook here, as thier are two tasks to be performed here.
- So firstly we have to create an ansible playbook, so they are simply ".yml" files, eg:
my_first_playbook.yml
- name: Install and Start Nginx
hosts: all
become: true
tasks:
- name: Install Nginix
apt:
name: Nginix
state: present
- name: Start Nginix Server
service:
name: Nginix
state: started
- to run this playbook we use command "ansible-playbook -i inventory my_first_playbook.yml "
- Now here "---" This means that this is an "yaml file".
- "-" means thier is list of tasks to perform.
- "name" means what actually this playbook does.
- "hosts" means on what servers you want this playbook to exceute things, in our case we
have given "all" that means all the servers listed in inventory file.
- "become" means grant root permisson to the playbook.
- tasks, are actually the things that you want to do on target servers.
- in taks "name" is similar like specifying what this task does.
- "apt" is like a module that is use to install the required package, can also do something
like shell: sudo apt install nginix, but ansible provides apt module for installing.
- "state" meaning what you want to install or to start, here present means install.
- "service" is an module that ansible provides for starting something, and here state is
started.
Efficient way of writing Ansible Playbooks.
so suppose we have given as task to create 3 EC2 instances and configure one of the EC2 instance as
Kubernetes Master Node, and 2 of them as Worker Nodes.
- so to do this task if we write this in a single ansible playbook the playbook will become huge and it will
be not manageable.
- so to write this types of tasks in an efficent manner we use "Ansible Playbook Roles".
- Ansible Roles are efficent way of writing complex ansible playbooks which will also increase efficeny of
the playbook.
- We can properly structure our playbook, so that it is easily manageable and can be debugged easily.
- to create a Role Playbook we use "ansible-galaxy role init kubernetes". (here kubernetes is name of role).
- This will create a folder named kubernetes inside we will have well structured ansible playbook files.
- The folder structure goes like this:
- we have file named "meta": in this file we write metadata like author, tags, etc.
- we have "defaults" in which we write some default variables which will be used by tasks we write.
- we have "vars" in which we specify variables if we require them in our playbook.
- we have "tests" in which tests are written.
- we have "handlers" in which we write exception handiling if any error comes how to configure it.
- we have "tasks" here we write our playbook.
